elements.text: What do we do during different seasons?

attributes.alt: Cover for Sometimes Rain, words by Meg Fleming, and illustrations by Diana Sudyka. The cover art shows two children and a dog running down a hill through the rain.

elements.text: Written by Meg Fleming, illustrated by Diana Sudyka
In this book, the author shares the joy and wonder of the changing seasons. It follows children in all kinds of weather through the seasons. It uses fun, rhyming words.

Pablo loves reading books about children having fun outdoors in winter, spring, summer and fall! Let’s find out what adventures they have.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
What things do the children do in each season?
Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
First drizzle, then rain!  Let’s use our fingers to show drizzle.
Now it’s winter. How can you tell it is cold there? How do the children have fun in the snow?
The snow has melted! It’s spring? What are the children doing?
Now it’s summer. You already know that it is hot in the summer. What things do the children do that look like fun in this hot weather?
Now it’s fall. What things do the children like to do?

Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
What things do the children do in each season?
The children make a snowman in winter.
The children look at clouds in spring.
The children stomp in crunchy leaves in the fall.
Write and read aloud a short sentence that tells what children do in one of the four seasons.
What do the children do in spring?
The children look at clouds in spring.
Which is your favorite season? What do you like to do?

It is important to introduce and practice letters that occur frequently in English words. This will allow you to create more decodable words, and children will begin to recognize letters and sounds more readily.
Share the Mind Builder: Ask and Answer Questions

Choose a partner and role-play having a conversation. Point out that you will take turns sharing information, and sometimes ask and answer each other’s questions. Model having a conversation about what you did this morning before school. Try to use question words
who, what, where, when, why, and how

Select pairs of children to have conversations, with one child asking the questions and the other child answering them. If time allows, have partners switch roles.

Gather clothing items for each season and put them in a basket. Ask one child to pull an item from the basket. Then invite the other children to ask questions for them to answer about the item. Choose a partner and model the activity using questions, such as,
Who might like to wear this? What season would someone wear this? When would you not want to wear this? What color is this?
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about the various animals the author showed in different seasons.

Turn-talking is found in cultures around the world! When children learn how to take turns talking and participate in conversations with their peers, they improve their speech and language skills. Turn-talking, initiating conversation, and active listening also help establish friendships among peers. (Stivers et al., 2009)
Bring in objects that reflect the season you are in. Invite children to observe, describe, and discuss the items. Make available a magnifying glass for study.

Providing children with songs, games, crafts, and books about the seasons can generate excitement about science. Outdoor nature walks provide excellent support for the theme! Learning about the seasons and their associated weather and natural changes will keep children eagerly awaiting each season.
Discuss with children all they have learned about seasons.
What are some things that happen in winter? What happens when spring comes?

Pair children and assign them a season. Ask them to act out a skit that gives clues about their assigned season. Challenge the other children to guess the season. Provide props (plastic pails, kites) and clothing and let children dress up!
Provide a writing prompt about how people enjoy the summer.

Introducing the seasons is a great way to teach related vocabulary. Provide descriptive words for each season (e.g. winter/cold/snow; spring/windy/flowers; summer/hot;/beach; fall/cool/pumpkins). Display cloze sentences to increase proficiently—for example: It is ____ in winter. (cold).

Invite children to take turns pretending to be a weather forecaster on TV. Give children a pretend microphone as a prop. Ask them to describe today’s weather. Then have them suggest activities that people might want to do in this kind of weather. Continue the focus with specific questions, such as,
Are the trees blooming? Are the leaves falling? Is it cold outside?
Today we are going to retell and reenact the book
Pablo loves to read rhyming picture books. This book is about the seasons. The pictures help us understand what the weather is like in each season.

This week we learned about the weather in each of the four seasons. We saw children enjoying outdoor activities. We saw animals and other living things in each season. As we read the book one more time, think about this question:
Which season do you like best and why?
Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to actively participate in the prompts below.
Brrr! It’s getting cold! Let’s pretend it is cold and give me your best shiver! Brrrr!
Let’s put on mittens so our hands stay toasty warm when we make a snowman.
Which do you think you would be better at, sledding or building a snowman?
Spring has arrived. Use your arms to flutter like a butterfly.
I see lots of green grass! What season is this? Let’s pretend to use a magnifying glass. What do you see?
It’s fall and getting chilly! Show me how you zip up your jackets. Even the ducks are chilly. They are flying south to warmer weather. What changes happen to the trees?
The children have been out playing again. Who is greeting the children at home and letting them know they are always welcome?
Invite children to turn and talk about the guiding question:
Which season do you like best and why?
I like winter because I like to play in the snow.
I like summer because I like to swim.
I like the fall because I like to jump in leaves.

Learning about how animals, plants, and weather are connected helps children understand how the physical world works. Children who are attuned to the environment are more apt to respect nature and make observations and predictions. These skills will help them become better critical thinkers.
